chapter: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: Question 1: Identify the marked layer of the retina.
questions.explanation:
199 
Sold by @itachibot The inner plexiform layer is the marked layer in the given histological image of retina, identified 
as the fourth layer from the uppermost (innermost) layer. The retina consists of 10 layers. The retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) is the outermost layer - 
below the Bruch's membrane of the choroid - and the internal limiting membrane is the innermost 
layer - separating the retina from the vitreous. The retinal pigment epithelium consists of a single layer of cells containing pigment. It is 
separated from the neurosensory retinal layers by the potential space between them which is 
known as interphotoreceptor matrix. The inner plexiform layer consists of synapsing nerve fibers. The axons of bipolar cells synapse 
with dendrites of ganglion cells; and both these processes synapse with processes 
of amacrine cells. It also contains some horizontally placed internal plexiform cells; and also a 
few ganglion cells.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 2: Identify the structure marked with red arrow 185 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The marked structure in the slide is the outer plexiform layer of the retina. The outer plexiform layer (outer synaptic layer) is present between the outer nuclear layer and the 
inner nuclear layer. This layer stains lightly. This layer consists of the axons of rods and cones 
which synapse with dendrites of bipolar neurons and horizontal cells. 200 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 3: The distance of the fovea from the temporal margin of the optic disc is  
.
questions.explanation:
The distance of the fovea from the temporal margin of the optic disc is 2 disc diameters. The fovea is an excavation in the retinal surface at the center of the macula, with a diameter of 1.5 
mm, which is about the same as that of the optic disc. The foveola forms the bottom of the fovea 
and has a diameter of 0.35 mm. It is devoid of ganglion cells. The umbo is the central floor the 
foveola, which corresponds to the foveolar light reflex. The foveal avascular zone (FAZ) is a central 
area (including foveola and surrounding areas) which contains no blood vessels but is surrounded 
by a continuous network of capillaries. The macula is a round area at the posterior pole, lying inside the temporal vascular arcades. It 
measures 5.5 mm in diameter. The inner layers of the macula contain the yellow xanthophyll 
carotenoid pigments lutein and zeaxanthin in far higher concentrations than the peripheral retina 
(hence, the full name "macula lutea", which means yellow plaque). 201 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: Question 4: Causes for expanding blind spot are all except
questions.explanation:
Optic disc hypoplasia does not cause enlargement of the blind spot. The physiological blind spot is an area of absolute scotoma in the visual field, seen in the region of 
optic disc. It is due to the absence of photoreceptors (rods and cones) in that region. Enlarged 
blind spot is seen in primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) (Option A), papilledema (Option C), 
medullated nerve fibers (Option D), optic disc drusen, coloboma of optic disc and myopic disc with a crescent. Optic nerve hypoplasia is the most common congenital optic disc anomaly. There is 
underdevelopment of the optic disc in the disease and it typically presents with a small disc that is 
surrounded by a yellowish pigmented ring, called the 'double ring sign'. Option A: In primary open-angle glaucoma(POAG), the optic disc enlargement is seen secondary 
to increased intra-ocular pressure (IOP) in the eye. Option C: Papilledema is a passive disc swelling seen with raised intracranial pressure. The blind 
spot is enlarged due to the edema of the optic disc. Option D: Medullated or opaque nerve fibers are the abnormal myelination of nerve fibers of the 
retina. Normally, optic nerve myelination stops at the level of lamina cribrosa. If the myelination 
continues beyond the optic disc it leads to the expansion of the blind spot. On ophthalmoscopic 
examination, these are seen as a whitish patch with feathery margins.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: Question 5: Which statement regarding Müller cells is false?

options.b: Their nuclei lie in the outer nuclear layer
options.c: Their foot processes form the inner & outer limiting membranes
options.d: They contribute to inner blood retinal barrier

questions.explanation:
The nuclei of Müller cells lie in the inner nuclear layer. Müller cells are a type of macroglial cells of the retina. The human retina contains 8–10 million 
Müller cells. Their nuclei lie in the inner nuclear layer and their processes extend across the 
retinal layers to form the inner and outer limiting membranes. Their functions include: 1. Providing structural stability to the retina 2. Interacting with other neurons and their functional and metabolic support 3. Providing neurons with trophic substances and removing metabolic waste 4. Playing a critical role in regulating the extracellular space volume as well as ion and water 
homeostasis and in maintaining the inner blood-retinal barrier Astrocytes are another type of macroglial cells of the retina. They play a crucial role in retinal 
vascularization. In the mature retina, they are restricted to the nerve fiber and ganglion cell 
layers.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following statements is false regarding the development of retinal vasculature?

options.a: Grow to temporal ora by 34 weeks of gestation
options.b: Grow to nasal ora by 36 weeks of gestation
options.c: Originate from mesenchymal tissue during week 16 of gestation

questions.explanation:
202 
Sold by @itachibot Retinal vessels reach temporal ora at approximately 40 weeks of gestation. Retinal vessels develop de novo from mesenchymal tissue, beginning during the 4th month of 
gestation. They radiate outward (centrifugally) from the optic nerve, reaching the nasal ora by 36 
weeks.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 7: A preterm baby treated for respiratory distress syndrome is found to have white pupillary 
reflex on opthalmologic examination. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
A preterm baby, treated for respiratory distress syndrome, with leucocoria (white pupillary reflex) 
most likely has retrolental fibroplasia. Retrolental fibroplasia, also known as retinopathy of prematurity, is a proliferative retinopathy. 
Risk factors include prematurity, very low birth weight and supplemental oxygen therapy (given 
for respiratory distress syndrome). ROP can be mild and may resolve spontaneously, but may lead 
to blindness in serious cases. 203 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 8: Which of the following is included under threshold disease when screening neonates for 
retinopathy of prematurity?

options.a: ROP stage 1 extending from 6'o clock to 11'0 clock in zone 1 with plus disease
options.b: ROP stage 3 extending from 2'o clock to 7'o clock in zone 2 with plus disease
options.c: ROP stage 3 extending from 1'o clock to 4'o clock in zone 1 without plus disease
options.d: ROP stage 2 extending from 3'o clock to 6'o clock in zone 2 with plus disease

questions.explanation:
ROP stage 3 extending from 2'0 clock to 7'o clock (6 clock hours) in zone 2 with plus disease fits 
into the definition of threshold disease. Threshold disease of retinopathy of prematurity is defined by the CRYO-ROP study as: • Stage 3 disease: Ridge with extraretinal fibrovascular proliferation into the vitreous • Involvement of zones 1 or 2 • Involvement of either at least 5 contiguous (continuous) clock hours or 8 non-contiguous clock 
hours • Associated with "plus disease": Dilatation and tortuosity of posterior pole vessels in at least two 
quadrants at the posterior pole. Treatment of threshold disease is laser photocoagulation of the involved part within 72 hours of 
diagnosis. Treatment of the various stages of ROP includes: • Pre-threshold type 1 disease - Treatment is now recommended within 48 hours and is done by 
laser photocoagulation of avascular retina. • Pre-threshold type 2 disease (Any ROP not following under type 1)- Observation for progression • Threshold disease - Laser photocoagulation of avascular retina • Aggresive posterior-ROP- Intravitreal anti-VEGF agents, eg., bevacizumab • Tractional retinal detachment (stage 4A) - Pars plana vitrectomy 204 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: Question 9: All of the following are true statements regarding retinopathy of prematurity except:

options.a: First screening should be done 32 weeks PMA or 4 weeks PNA, whichever is later
options.b: For infants less than 28 week, screen at 3 week of postnatal age to detect APROP
options.c: Neonates are best examined at ophthalmology OPD and hence should be transported
options.d: Screening is done using indirect ophthalmoscopy by an expert ophthalmologist

questions.explanation:
Neonates are best examined in the neonatal unit itself under the supervision of the attending 
neonatologist. It is not recommended to transport infants to the ophthalmic outpatient 
department for examination. The first screening examination should be carried out by indirect ophthalmoscopy at 32 weeks 
PMA or 4 weeks PNA, whichever is later. For infants born at less than 28 weeks, screening is done 
at 3 weeks PNA to detect APROP. Aggressive posterior ROP ("rush" disease, AP-ROP), if 
untreated, usually progresses to total retinal detachment (stage 5) within a few days. It is 
characterized by its posterior location, prominence of plus disease and ill-defined nature of the 
retinopathy.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 10: A preterm neonate admitted to NICU who received supplemental oxygen is being screened 
for retinopathy of prematurity. Fundus examination reveals a subtotal retinal detachment. 
How will you stage the disease?
questions.explanation:
Subtotal retinal detachment is considered to be stage 4 of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). The clinical staging of ROP is as follows: • Stage 1 - Formation of a demarcation line at the edge of vessels, dividing the vascular from the 
avascular retina. • Stage 2- Formation of an intraretinal ridge • Stage 3- Ridge with extraretinal fibrovascular proliferation into the vitreous • Stage 4- Subtotal retinal detachment • Stage 5- Total retinal detachment 205 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 11: A 14-day-old neonate born at 28 weeks of gestation had developed respiratory distress 
syndrome at birth. You want to screen for retinopathy of prematurity. How many weeks from 
now would you schedule the screening?
questions.explanation:
In the scenario above, the postnatal age of the premature infant is 2 weeks, and therefore, the 
infant must be screened in 2 weeks i.e., 4 weeks of postnatal age, as per the guidelines for the 
management of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). ROP guidelines state that the first examination should be performed between 4 and 6 weeks of 
postnatal age (after birth) or between 31–33 weeks of post-conceptional age (calculated as 
gestational age + postnatal age), whichever is later. Ideally, 2 examinations must be performed; 
however, 1 may suffice if it shows complete retinal vascularisation.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following is the most important factor for the development of diabetic 
retinopathy?
questions.explanation:
206 
Sold by @itachibot The most important factor for the development of diabetic retinopathy is the duration of diabetes. Diabetic retinopathy constitutes the retinal changes seen in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. 
The most important factor for its development is duration of diabetes after the onset of puberty, 
followed by glycemic control. It is more common in type 1 diabetes mellitus. The presence of 
hypertension increases the risk of diabetic retinopathy. First fundus examination for type 1 diabetes is done after 5 years after diagnosis and for type 2 is 
done at the time of diagnosis. The frequency of follow-up for types 1 and 2 diabetes mellitus is 
every year. Diabetes in pregnancy is followed up every 3 months. The earliest feature of diabetic retinopathy is microaneurysms, which are present in the inner 
nuclear layer of the retina.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 13: Which of the following findings on a fundus examination would suggest severe 
non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy?

options.a: Significant venous beading in any of the 4 quadrants

questions.explanation: Severe hemorrhages in all 4 quadrants is a feature of severe NPDR. Note: Macular star is a feature of malignant hypertensive retinopathy.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 14: A person is diagnosed to have diabetes on his 45th birthday. When will you recommend a 
dilated fundus examination for him?

options.d: When he complains of decrease in vision

questions.explanation:
A 45 year old diagnosed with diabetes mellitus is likely to have type 2 diabetes and thus, he should 
undergo screening for diabetic retinopathy immediately. Duration of diabetes is the most important risk factor for developing diabetic retinopathy, 
especially proliferative diabetic retinopathy. The recommendations for first fundus examination in 
diabetic retinopathy is: • Within 3-5 years of diagnosis in type 1 diabetes • Immediately in type 2 diabetes. 207 
Sold by @itachibot Later, the screening is continued once every year in both Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes. In the event 
proliferative diabetic retinopathy develops, screening is done more frequently - once every 2 
months.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: Question 15: ETDRS study was related to?
questions.explanation:
Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) was a randomized clinical trial that studied 
the effect of photocoagulation on diabetic macular edema. The results of the study demonstrated the beneficial effects of focal photocoagulation on diabetic 
macular edema. The study resulted in the recommendation that all eyes with clinically significant 
diabetic macular edema should be considered for focal photocoagulation.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 16: A patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension underwent fundus fluorescent 
angiography (FFA) to evaluate his decreasing vision. The FFA yields an image as shown 
below, which is characteristic of: 189 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The fundus fluorescent angiography (FFA) image shows enlarged foveal avascular zone, seen as a 
hypofluorescent patch in the macula (white arrow), with surrounding capillary non perfused areas 
(blue arrow). Both of these are suggestive of macular ischemia. The above mentioned findings when combined with the history of diabetes in this patient points 
towards the diagnosis of diabetic macular ischemia. FFA images in a case of diabetic retinopathy are given below: • Non proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR) • Punctate or pinpoint areas of hyperfluorescence - microaneurysms • Abnormal branching of arteriovenous shunt - intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) • Patchy filling defects of ischemia due to capillary atrophy or non perfusion 208 
Sold by @itachibot • Increase in the size of hypoperfusion in foveal avascular zone in macular ischemia 2. Proliferative diabetic retinopathy(PDR) • Fluorescein leakage - in retinal neovascularization. • Leakage in the disc region suggests neovascularization of the disc (NVD) and leakage in other 
regions suggests neovascularization elsewhere (NVE). The image below shows pinpoint areas of hyperfluorescence and areas of fluorescein leakage in 
the fundus. Option B: Macular edema also known as cystoid macular edema (CME) is a collection of fluid 
between the outer plexiform layer and the inner nuclear layer of the retina following a break in the 
blood-retina barrier. On fundoscopy, a honeycomb appearance is seen, and on FFA, flower petal 
pattern can be seen. The below image shows the flower petal pattern on FFA as seen in CME. 209 
Sold by @itachibot Option C: Submacular hemorrhage also known as subretinal hemorrhage will obscure the 
choroidal dye visualization and appaers as ill defined areas of hypoperfusion in the corresponding 
area. The retinal vessels overlying the area would, however will be visualized. There are no 
assosciated features of pinpoint hyperfluorescence and vascular leakage that are usually seen with 
diabetic macular ischemia. The below given images show fluorescein angiography which reveal 
blocked fluorescence in the maculae of both eyes due to subretinal hemorrhages. Option D: Premacular hemorrhage is a term used to define vitreous hemorrhage that occurs in the 
subhyaloid space. It is seen as a region of hypofluorescence with no overlying retinal vasculature 
visualization on FFA.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 17: A 69-year-old patient with hypertension has silver wiring, papilledema, and arteriovenous 
nipping visible on fundoscopy, but no other changes. How would you grade his disease?
questions.explanation:
210 
Sold by @itachibot A patient with hypertension having "silver wiring," papilledema, and arteriovenous nipping visible 
on fundoscopy has Grade IV retinopathy.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 18: A 40-year-old male, newly diagnosed with systolic hypertension, presents with a three-week 
history of bilateral blurry vision. His visual acuity is 20/30 and 20/120 in the right and left 
eye, respectively. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following 
findings is least likely to be seen on his fundoscopy?
questions.explanation:
Systolic hypertension (systolic blood pressure over 200 mm Hg) with bilateral blurry vision and 
unremarkable examination findings point to a diagnosis of hypertensive retinopathy. Intra-retinal 
microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) are not seen in hypertensive retinopathy. IRMA is a feature 
of diabetic retinopathy. Arteriolar narrowing occurs due to vasoconstriction and sclerosis of retinal vessels due to 
hypertension. Cotton wool spots are areas of nerve fibre layer infarcts. They occur due to capillary 
obliteration in hypertension. 211 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 19: The following image shows the picture of the fundus in a patient taken 48 hours after 
sustaining severe head trauma. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The image shows multiple cotton wool spots around the disc. This is Purtschers' 
retinopathy, which is classically associated with severe head injury. It is also seen in pancreatitis and chest trauma due to fat/air embolism. Ophthalmoscopy reveals 
multiple, variably sized cotton-wool spots and intraretinal hemorrhages around the optic nerve. 
There is no effective treatment.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following statements is not true regarding sickle cell retinopathy?

options.a: Sea-fan appearance is seen in supero-temporal quadrant.
options.b: HbSS has more severe ocular manifestations than HbSC.
options.d: Central retinal vein occlusion may be seen.

questions.explanation:
Hemoglobin SC and S-Thal disease have the most severe ocular manifestations, although sickle SS 
disease has the most severe systemic manifestations. The incidence of proliferative retinopathy in SC disease (Hb SC) is 33%, sickle cell thalassemia 
(Hb S-Thal) is 14%, SS disease (Hb SS) is 3%. In sickle cell retinopathy, elevated blood viscosity 
may occlude venules and arterioles, as well as capillaries. The following fundus findings can be 
noted as a result: • Retinal vascular peripheral non-perfusion • Retinal hemorrhages: "salmon patches," "iridescent spots," and "black sunbursts" are hallmarks 
of nonproliferative sickle cell retinopathy. • Peripheral retinal neovascularization in a "sea fan" configuration is the hallmark of proliferative 
sickle cell retinopathy. They are also described as "parachute" lesions. They are most commonly 
found in the supero-temporal vascular arcades. • Angioid streaks (Rupture of Bruch’s membrane) Conjunctival "comma-shaped" capillaries and iris atrophy are other ocular findings seen. 
Complications of sickle cell retinopathy include central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) (occurs due 
to retinal hypoxia), vitreous hemorrhage and tractional retinal detachment. The image below shows 'sea fans' as seen on fluorescein angiography. 212 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 21: Roth spots are seen in  
. 191 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Roth's spots are seen in acute leukemia. Roth's spots are retinal hemorrhages with white or pale center. The white centre due to coagulated 
fibrin-platelet plug is surrounded by red rim that is caused by hemorrhage. Roth's spots may be 
seen in: • Subacute bacterial endocarditis • Leukemia • Diabetes • Sickle cell retinopathy • Hypertensive retinopathy • HIV retinopathy • Systemic lupus erythematosus The fundus image below shows Roth's spots. 213 
Sold by @itachibot Option B: Uveal melanoma devolps due to malignant transformation of the normal melanocytes 
present in the uveal tissue. Primary posterior uveal melanoma (choroidal melanoma) which forms 
the majority of uveal melanoma manifests as: • A solitary elevated subretinal grey-brown dome shaped mass • "Collar stud" appearance on B-scan - when the tumor breaks through the Bruchs membrane and 
protrudes into subretinal space • "Double circulation" sign Primary anterior uveal melanoma frequently involves the iris and presents as nodular melanocytic 
mass on the iris. The below given fundus image shows the "double circulation sign" of choroidal 
melanoma. Option C: Uveal lymphoma is characterized by localized or diffuse uveal infiltrates of malignant 
lymphoma cells. Fundus examination in these patients show diffuse creamy thickening of 
posterior uvea with nodular accentuation. 214 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 22: A 7-year-old boy presents with 6/6 vision in the right eye and vision for only hand movements 
in the left eye. On fundoscopy, the right eye appears normal. The left eye shows retinal 
detachment, subretinal yellowish exudates, and telangiectatic vessels. What is the most 
probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Unilateral decreased vision with retinal detachment, subretinal yellowish exudates and 
telangiectatic vessels in a young boy points to the diagnosis of Coats' disease. Coats’ disease, described by Coats in 1908, affects boys three times more often than girls, has no 
reported racial or ethnic predilection, and is usually unilateral. The average age at diagnosis is 8–
16 years. The clinical course is generally progressive. It is characterized by discrete zones of retinal vascular abnormalities like aneurysmal dilatation 
and leakage. It is associated with localized lipid deposition (hard exudates) and varying degrees of 
subretinal exudates. Vessels may appear telangiectatic, and they may have aneurysms that are 
grape-like, clustered, or light bulb-shaped. The image below depicts the typical vascular abnormalities with aneurysmal dilatation, 
telangiectasia, exudation, and severe lipid deposition in the macula which are seen in Coat's 
disease.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 23: A 64-year-old female presented with complaints of blurring of vision and pain in her left eye. 
She also gave a history of redness in her left eye about 3 months back, which she passed off as 
normal conjunctivitis. On tonometry, the IOP is 55 mm Hg. The slit-lamp revealed rubeosis 
iridis in all four quadrants. The fundus picture of the patient is given below. What is the most 
probable diagnosis? 192 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Monocular blurring of vision and pain with "splashed sauce" appearance on fundoscopy points 
towards a diagnosis of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). Ischemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) is characterised by sudden visual loss. There is 
splashed sauce appearance on fundoscopy due to retinal hemorrhages. Risk factors include high 
intraocular pressure (IOP), hypertension and blood viscosity syndromes. Its complications include neovascularisation of the iris (rubeosis iridis) and neovascular glaucoma 
(NVG). NVG typically occurs 3 months after the occlusive event. Up to 50% of eyes develop NVG 
following ischaemic CRVO. Pan-retinal photocoagulation is the treatment of choice. 215 
Sold by @itachibot CRVO is classified into two types: • Ischemic CRVO: Characterized by relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), markedly reduced 
visual acuity, and many cotton-wool spots • Non-ischemic CRVO: Characterized by normal pupillary reaction, reduced visual acuity, and few 
cotton-wool spots Treatment usually involves treating the underlying cause and complications.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 24: A man with history of hypertension and loss of vision in the left eye has the following 
fundoscopy findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The image above demonstrates characteristic flame-shaped hemorrhages, localized to the 
superotemporal sector of the retina. The image, along with loss of vision and history of 
hypertension, points to a diagnosis of branched retinal vein occlusion (BRVO), specifically 
affecting the superotemporal branch of the retinal vein. Occlusion of a single branch of the retinal vein leads to branched retinal vein occlusion. This 
occlusion leads to impaired venous drainage, resulting in the accumulation of blood within the 
retina. The visual defect in BRVO tends to be partial. Note: The different types of retinal vascular obstructions are branched retinal vein obstruction 
(BRVO), central retinal vein obstruction (CRVO), branched retinal artery obstruction (BRAO) and 
central retinal artery obstruction (CRAO). Retinal vein occlusion (RVO) is the second most 
common retinal vascular disorder after diabetic retinopathy. In CRVO, tortuosity and engorgement of all branches of the central retinal vein are seen, affecting 
all quadrants of the retina.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 25: A 67-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden painless vision loss in 
his left eye. He has had a similar episode before but his vision was quickly restored. On 
physical exam, a carotid bruit is heard and a relative afferent pupillary defect is noted on 
ocular examination. His fundus appears as shown below. Which of the following is the best 
immediate step in the management of this condition? 193 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Sudden painless unilateral vision loss with carotid bruit (carotid artery disease) and the fundus 
picture showing a cherry-red spot is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). The 
best immediate step in management is ocular massage among the given options. Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) occurs due to obstruction of the retinal artery at the level 
of lamina cribrosa. Risk factors include heart disease, carotid artery disease, mucormycosis, 
varicella infection, radiation exposure and trauma. It may be caused by the following: • Emboli of carotid artery or cardiac origin are the most common cause of CRAO. Other emboli 
are cholesterol emboli, calcium emboli, and platelet fibrin emboli • Atherosclerosis-related thrombosis • Retinal arteritis with obliteration • Angiospasm • Raised intraocular pressure • Thrombophilic disorders 216 
Sold by @itachibot Patients often present with sudden painless monocular loss of vision with history of a similar 
episode that resolved spontaneously (amaurosis fugax). On examination, direct pupillary reflex is 
absent and relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is positive. Fundus examination shows 
marked attenuation of arteries (thread like arteries), interrupted blood flow in vein (cattle 
track appearance), cherry red spot, severe edema and retinal pallor. A cherry-red spot of the macula is typical and arises in this area because of the absence of 
ganglion cells at the foveola resulting in the transmission of the normal choroidal color. This in 
contrast to the surrounding area where intense retinal whitening blocks the transmission of the 
normal choroidal color. Treatment is to dislodge the emboli by suddenly decreasing the IOP by IV acetazolamide or ocular 
massage. Ocular massage is considered the most effective method. Other treatment options 
include IV mannitol, vasodilators (nitrates), fibrinolytic therapy, or laser photodisruption in some 
cases. In cases of giant cell arteritis, steroids are beneficial.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 26: A 52-year-old woman presents with complaints of sudden painless loss of vision in the left eye 
since yesterday. She also gives a history of temporal headaches, myalgias, and pain in the jaw 
while chewing. Examination of the left eye reveals a visual acuity of HM+ and an RAPD. 
Fundus examination of the left eye shows cattle trucking of blood within the retinal veins on 
applying gentle pressure. Which of the following is the likely cause of fundal findings?

options.c: Non- ischemic central retinal venous occlusion

questions.explanation:
A 52-year-old woman temporal headaches, myalgias and pain in the jaw while chewing likely has 
giant cell arteritis (GCA). Given that she has sudden painless monocular loss of vision with RAPD 
and points to a diagnosis of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). GCA is the most common primary vasculitis in adults. It is a risk factor for the development of 
CRAO. CRAO occurs due to obstruction of the retinal artery at the level of lamina cribrosa. When 
obstruction to the blood flow is not complete, the flow may be partially restored. Thus, gentle 
pressure upon the globe may break the column of venous blood into red beads separated by clear 
interspaces. This gives the characteristic 'cattle truck' appearance. Option A: Ischemic CRVO shows a characteristic "splashed tomato sauce" appearance on 
fundoscopy. Option C: Non-Ischemic CRVO does not present with such a severe loss of visual acuity. Option D: Branched retinal artery occlusion presents with hemifield visual defects.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 27: A 60-year-old man presents with sudden painless loss of vision. Fundoscopy findings are 
shown below. Which of the following findings do you expect in this patient? 194 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Sudden painless monocular loss of vision with fundoscopy showing Hollehorst 
plaque is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). Relative afferent pupillary defect is 
seen in these cases. Hollenhorst plaques are cholesterol emboli that are seen in retinal arterioles. On fundus 
examination, it gives an appearance of a refractile yellow-white color substance in the retinal 
vessels. Note: Although elevated intraocular pressure has been implicated as a cause of central retinal 
artery obstruction, it is unlikely that intraocular pressure can be raised high enough to block 
arterial inflow to the eye 217 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 28: A 61-year-old university professor presents with a loss of vision in his left eye. He describes 
the sensation that a curtain was coming up over his affected eye. In addition, 7 days ago the 
patient noticed what he described as flashing lights and floaters. He gives a history of having 
cataract surgery in the same eye 3 weeks ago. A B-scan image of his left eye is shown below. 
Which of the following statements best describes the pathology? 195 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: Fibrovascular membranes in the vitreous causing traction
options.c: Fluid accumulation between NSR and RPE due to retinal tear
options.d: Fluid accumulation between NSR and RPE due to choroidal exudation

questions.explanation:
The prodromal symptoms of flashing lights, floaters followed by loss of monocular vision (curtain 
over the eye) and the B-scan suggest a diagnosis of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. 
Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is the result of the accumulation of fluid between NSR and 
RPE due to a retinal tear. Retinal detachment is the separation of the neurosensory retina from the retinal pigment 
epithelium. Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is the most common type of retinal detachment. 
It occurs due to fluid accumulation after a retinal break (tear). High myopia, trauma, 
pseudophakia, aphakia are predisposing factors. Patients present with photopsia (flashes of light 
due to vitreoretinal traction at the site of the break), floaters and visual field defect (black 
curtain/veil in front of the eye). Signs include hypotony, as the liquefied vitreous in the subretinal space is absorbed through the 
RPE and Shafers sign or tobacco dusting (pigments in the anterior vitreous). The detached retina 
is convex in configuration. The surface is corrugated with undulations. The most dangerous type 
of retinal break is horseshoe tear and the most dangerous location of retinal break is the 
supero-temporal retina. Treatment is by prophylactic laser barrage, scleral buckling, pneumatic retinopexy and pars plana 
vitrectomy. Other types of retinal detachment are tractional and exudative type: Tractional retinal detachment occurs when fibro-vascular membranes in the vitreous due to 
long-standing retinal neovascularization exert traction on the retina. It is seen in proliferative 
diabetic retinopathy, central retinal venous occlusion, Eales disease and ROP. The detached retina 
is concave in configuration. No breaks are seen. Treatment is with pars plana vitrectomy with 
endo photocoagulation. Exudative retinal detachment is seen when exudative fluid from the choroid collects in the 
subretinal space. Patients present with visual field defects, floaters due to vitritis but no 218 
Sold by @itachibot photopsia. The detached retina is convex in configuration. The surface is smooth. No break is 
seen. Shifting fluid is seen. The image below shows a fundus which reveals retinal detachment inferiorly from 3-9 o'clock with 
tear at 3:30.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 29: Pneumatic retinopexy is an outpatient procedure where retinal detachment is sealed with air 
insufflation. Which of the following gases would you use while performing the said 
procedure?
questions.explanation:
Sulphur hexafluoride is the gas used in pneumatic retinopexy for the treatment of retinal 
detachments Pneumatic retinopexy is used for the treatment of fresh retinal detachments with a single retinal 
break in the superior two-thirds of the fundus. In this procedure, a bubble is injected intravitreally 
through the conjunctiva and postoperatively the patient is positioned so that the bubble 
tamponades the retinal break against the retinal pigment epithelium. 219 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 30: A 24-year-old woman who is 8 months pregnant, myopic, and diabetic presents to you with 
sudden painless loss of vision in her right eye. She is a known case of Eales' disease. Her 
blood pressure is 170/110 mmHg. Which of her conditions is responsible for a fundus finding 
of retinal detachment with a positive shifting fluid sign?
questions.explanation:
Exudative retinal detachment is characterized by positive shifting fluid sign. Among her 
conditions, toxemia of pregnancy is one of the causes of exudative retinal detachment. Exudative retinal detachment occurs due to the presence of subretinal fluid in the absence of tear 
or traction. It is caused by: • Malignant melanoma of the choroid • Retinoblastoma • Vogt–Koyanagi–Harada (VKH) syndrome • Uveal effusion syndrome • Posterior scleritis • Coat’s disease • Malignant hypertension • Pregnancy-induced hypertensive retinopathy • Sympathetic ophthalmitis Patients present with sudden and painless diminution of vision, visual field defects and grey reflex 
(detached retina looks grey). Indirect ophthalmoscopy is the investigation of choice. The image depicts retinal detachment showing a smooth, detached convex retina with subretinal 
fluid.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: Question 31: Shifting fluid sign is seen in?
questions.explanation:
220 
Sold by @itachibot The presence of shifting fluid is a hallmark feature of serous or exudative retinal detachment. In serous retinal detachment, there is a subretinal accumulation of the serous fluid mostly due 
to the breakdown in the blood-retinal barrier. When the position of the head is altered, the fluid 
shifts to the dependent portion. Serous retinal detachment has a smooth convex configuration. A 
retinal tear or preretinal traction is absent. Other options: Option B: Traction RD has a concave configuration and breaks are absent. Retinal mobility is 
severely reduced and shifting fluid is absent. Option C: Rhegmatogenous RD presents with tobacco dust in anterior vitreous with substantial 
vitreous blood or inflammatory cells. Retinal breaks are also seen.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 32: Hollenhorst plaques are seen in  
.
questions.explanation:
Hollenhorst plaques are seen in central retinal arterial occlusion (CRAO). They are cholesterol emboli seen in retinal arterioles. They originate from atherosclerotis plaques 
in larger arteries. The image below shows Hollenhorst plaques (arrow).
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: Question 33: Identify the condition.
questions.explanation:
The above image shows a loss of foveal reflex and central serous retinopathy, therefore showing 
focal foveal detachment. There is oedema at the fovea signifying foveal detachment from underlying retinal pigment 
epithelium. Macular oedema is also present (grey dull retina with a ring reflex around the site of 
oedema). Thus, the most appropriate choice would be foveal detachment. 221 
Sold by @itachibot Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of neurosensory retina in the 
macular region. It occurs due to increased permeability of choriocapillaris, leading to fluid 
accumulation in the subretinal space. Therefore, it is now known as central 
serous choriopathy (CSC). If there is serous retinal detachment at macula, there is sudden painless loss of vision. Patients 
also have relative positive scotoma, micropsia and metamorphopsia. On ophthalmoscopy, a 
circular ring reflex present. The foveal reflex is absent. On fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA), 
an enlarging ink-blot pattern or smoke-stack pattern is seen. Treatment is generally not required. It is usually self-limiting, but often recurrent. Steroids are 
contraindicated.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 34: In which of the following conditions is the given sign seen? 197 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image depicts fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) showing an enlarging ink-blot 
pattern/enlarging dot sign, which is seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR). Smokestack 
appearance is another pattern of fundus seen in CSR and is a characteristic sign of this condition. Amsler grid is used for: • Assess macular function and detecting maculopathy. • Evaluate the visual field of 10° • Good for follow-up in CSR 222 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question:
Question 35: The ETDRS chart is used for visual evaluation in diabetic patients. What does ETDRS stand 
for?

options.a: Between the Bruch membrane and retinal pigment epithelium
options.c: Between the outer plexiform layer and inner nuclear layer

questions.explanation:
ETDRS stands for Early Treatment for Diabetic Retinopathy Study. ETDRS was a clinical trial designed to evaluate if argon laser photocoagulation or aspirin 
treatment can reduce the risk of visual loss or slow the progression of diabetic retinopathy in 
patients with mild-to-severe nonproliferative or early proliferative diabetic retinopathy. During 
the study, three new visual acuity charts were created in place of Snellen's visual chart. 223 
Sold by @itachibot Macular disorders, Retinal dystrophies, and Vitreal disorders
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment
